#2369: To a comment on #2314, "No sorority sisters all secretly hate each other UNLESS they were friends before pledging. .. you're friendship is safe":

First of all, *your.

Secondly, it breaks my heart when students who aren't members of the greek community project ignorant stereotypes like this. To be honest, I didn't have friends going into recruitment my freshman year. There were girls on my floor that I hung out with, but I wouldn't call any of them friends. I was miserable. I spent winter break filling out transfer applications. I rushed because my mother, father and brother were members of greek life, and they all encouraged me to stick it out though recruitment. Joining a sorority was the best decision I've made in my college career thus far. I've met incredible and inspiring women who I will be friends with well beyond my four years of college. Though I can't honestly say that I'm best friends with every single girl, but I know I can rely on any sister when I'm in need. And THAT is sisterhood. You don't have to be best friends to be sisters. Please don't put down my sisterhood simply because you don't understand it.

#2316: I didn't get into the sorority I wanted but joined the one that did take me. Today I watched friends from afar all happy with their new sisters and I sadly couldn't help but feel resentful.

#2381: Dear Poster #2316,
I was in your shoes exactly one year ago. I got a bid from the sorority not of my choice, and watched my roommate get hugged by 100 girls in the sorority I put as my #1. I'm not going to lie to you, it hurt for a while, and because I felt rejected it took me a long time to open up to the girls in the sorority I took the bid from. Once I finally did though, I found my niche. And after spending a year in Greek Life I am 100% sure that the sorority that chose me is truly the one for me, not the one I thought I wanted after a week of superficial recruitment conversations. The chapters have on average 150 girls; put yourself out there and I know you'll find the sisters you belong with!

Acutane. That shit cured my 10 out of 10 acne. Might get Crohns later, but at least I have a pretty face now

Sometimes acne is a sign of uncleanliness, which would turn people off. But personally, it wouldn't turn me off if I were to kiss someone with acne. You can usually tell when it's due to dirty hands or not. lol
Also, sorry if this is weird, but it's something I really like helping people with: feel free to send me a message if you want any advice, or just want someone to vent to lol

http://www.reddit.com/r/skincareaddiction I went from about a 5 in acne to about a 1 in acne in large part because of this site... Acne is not a permanent condition, and I know it sucks -- but it can be cured. Exhaust every resource before accutane. Consider prescription grade topicals from a dermatologist if you're impatient, or if nothing else seems to work.

tip #1: Many if not most drugstore products are doing more harm than good to your skin. Invest time in true RESEARCH, as in based in science, if you have not done so already. That site I mentioned has many resources to do so.

Right there with you Taylor.  

You'll notice your skin more than any lady, but if it bothers you & you've tried everything, Accutane could be an option.

#2369: To a comment on #2314, "No sorority sisters all secretly hate each other UNLESS they were friends before pledging. .. you're friendship is safe":

First of all, *your.

Secondly, it breaks my heart when students who aren't members of the greek community project ignorant stereotypes like this. To be honest, I didn't have friends going into recruitment my freshman year. There were girls on my floor that I hung out with, but I wouldn't call any of them friends. I was miserable. I spent winter break filling out transfer applications. I rushed because my mother, father and brother were members of greek life, and they all encouraged me to stick it out though recruitment. Joining a sorority was the best decision I've made in my college career thus far. I've met incredible and inspiring women who I will be friends with well beyond my four years of college. Though I can't honestly say that I'm best friends with every single girl, but I know I can rely on any sister when I'm in need. And THAT is sisterhood. You don't have to be best friends to be sisters. Please don't put down my sisterhood simply because you don't understand it.

honestly, i dont think anyone NEEDS to come out. do people have to announce what flavor of ice cream they prefer? and if they did, would anyone really care? however, if you feel like coming out will help you be more comfortable with yourself, then by all means do it! im pansexual, which means im basically genderblind and find myself attracted to people regardless of gender. ive been called greedy and confused and, yes, ive been accused of having "special snowflake syndrome". but you know what? none of my FRIENDS have ever said that. i didnt know what i was until last year; up until then i thought i was just bisexual. its never too late to find something out about yourself, and if your friends really love you for who you are, then coming out shouldnt change that.                                                                                                       anyway, TL;DR, if you wanna come out then GO FOR IT! Your friends will be behind you every step of the way :)

You should do what you feel will ultimately make you happy :) UM is not for everyone and you know what, that is completely ok! It's hard picking a college and sometimes you gotta pick more than once. Personally, I was in love as soon as I got a brochure and then went to heaven/got the zing feeling as soon as I stepped on to campus haha

I did it and I've never been happier. I miss my friends a LOT, but I just make plans to visit them. I'm saving a lot of money at my new school, and I'm closer to family. Feel free to message me if you have questions or just want to talk about it

Consider talking to UM's counselors. The transition to college is one of the most difficult things a person does in their life. Counseling at UM is top-notch and they help a lot of people. Whether you're dealing with stress, depression, or just want somebody to talk to. It's free if you have UM's health insurance and confidential.

data.message: Excuse me, but you are extremely rude and disrespectful. The fact that a woman has a smaller butt or boobs than other women does not make her any less of a woman. There are many other characteristics of womanhood that you need to learn to consider and know that the size of a woman's ass or her breasts does not define whether or not she can be considered a woman.

It's important to remember that the shape of a WOMAN'S body is primarily due to genetics. Yeah everyone has their preferences but it is extremely rude to devalue someone based on their body type when it's not something they can control.

Well....just do something about your weight then, if it worries you so much.
I mean at least it sounds like you've got a nice sense of humor!
Sami Bara
Shut up Meg

My dear don't say this sort of thing about yourself! First weight is absolutely not everything. Second, its also not irrelevant. It's good to be healthy and being overweight isn't. Third, its in your control! I know that's easier said than done, but I've known a few others to have committed to losing weight, and really lost all of it. If you want to lose the weight, you absolutely can. You have a part of you that fights against this. Well this part is henceforth absolutely without authority! You might feel miserable, you might want to come up with exceptions and excuses to break whatever system you set up, but you have to pretend like that's simply out of the question. Fourth, take up exercise with your diet. If it bores you, take up a group activity like Karate or something. Being part of a group is motivating. And finally, most importantly, you have to be certain you can do this. You can! You got yourself here and you can get yourself out. As long as you don't believe that, the problem is your attitude towards you, not everyone else's. I'm confident you can do this. It's not gonna be easy (but its also not impossibly hard!), but I assure you by year's end you can have totally changed yourself. This is your project, do it! And best of luck!
I am certain that you are truly beautiful.

#2322: I'm debating getting a new bunch of friends. I honestly feel like my current friendships have run their courses and that I have little to nothing in common with my friends now. I need to get away from their negativity and honestly, it's just boring now. I think I deserve positive and supportive friends for a change.
Thats where you find your real friends as oppossed to people who just view you as a clown for entertainment.
Message me if you ever want to talk! I've felt EXACTLY the same way in the past.

Just in case the other two people aren't enough, feel free to talk to me. I spent a fair deal of high school feeling like that, and the first step to getting over it is just letting it out and talking to someone about your problems.

You'd be surprised how many people are doing the same thing, i still worry about that from time to time myself. Your friends will still like you if you let them know how you're feeling, the world isn't always as cruel as it seems to be through the lens of depression.
Mickey Lebowski i'm here for u

Love,
